instruction: A 65-year-old male with Type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up. Current A1C is 8.5%. He has hypertension and stage 3 CKD (eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73m2). Current medications: metformin 1000mg BID. BP: 145/90 mmHg. Provide a comprehensive treatment plan.
sol: Consider adding SGLT2 inhibitor or GLP-1 RA for A1C reduction and cardio-renal benefits
Add ACE inhibitor or ARB for BP control and kidney protection
Target A1C < 7.0-7.5% based on age and comorbidities
Lifestyle modifications: diet, exercise, weight management
Monitor kidney function and adjust medications as needed

instruction: A 45-year-old female with Type 1 diabetes for 20 years presents. She uses insulin glargine 20 units nightly and lispro 1:10 carb ratio. Her A1C is 7.8%. She reports frequent hypoglycemia, especially at night. She wants to pregnancy. Discuss management adjustments.
sol: Switch to CGM for better glucose monitoring
Consider insulin pump for tighter control
Adjust basal insulin to reduce nocturnal hypoglycemia
Pre-conception counseling: target A1C < 6.5%
Add folic acid supplementation
Refer to high-risk obstetrics and maternal-fetal medicine

instruction: A 58-year-old male presents with chest pain. ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4. Cardiac enzymes are elevated. BP 100/60, HR 95. Describe immediate management and treatment plan.
sol: Immediate activation of cath lab for PCI
Dual antiplatelet therapy: aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor
Anticoagulation with heparin
High-intensity statin therapy
Nitroglycerin for pain relief
Beta-blocker if hemodynamically stable

instruction: A 72-year-old female presents with confusion, fever, and dysuria. Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria. BP 85/55, HR 120, Temp 102Â°F. Provide diagnosis and management plan.
sol: Diagnosis: urosepsis with septic shock
Immediate fluid resuscitation with crystalloids
Blood cultures, then broad-spectrum antibiotics (ceftriaxone or meropenem)
Urine culture and sensitivity
Monitor lactate, repeat vitals
Admit to ICU for sepsis management

instruction: A 28-year-old male with Type 1 diabetes uses an insulin pump. His A1C is 9.2%. He reports frequent DKA episodes due to pump occlusion. He is interested in switching to multiple daily injections. Provide transition plan.
sol: Calculate total daily dose (TDD) from pump history
Start basal-bolus regimen: basal insulin (glargine/detemir) 50% of TDD
Mealtime insulin (rapid-acting) 50% divided among meals
Carbohydrate counting education
Sick day rules to prevent DKA
Close glucose monitoring during transition

instruction: A 65-year-old female with atrial fibrillation, CHF (EF 35%), and hypertension presents. Current meds: metoprolol 25mg BID, lisinopril 10mg daily. She has had one TIA. Discuss anticoagulation and rhythm management.
sol: Start anticoagulation: DOAC (apixaban or rivaroxaban) preferred over warfarin
CHA2DS2-VASc score indicates high stroke risk
Continue rate control with beta-blocker
Consider rhythm control if symptomatic despite rate control
Evaluate for catheter ablation if appropriate
Continue ACE inhibitor for HF and BP
